Here's Vitalik's description of BTC maximalism: "idea that multiple competing cryptocurrencies is undesirable, that it is wrong to launch altcoins, and that it is righteous & inevitable that the Bitcoin currency comes to take a monopoly position in the cryptocurrency scene."

It's ironic, really. I was originally labeled a Bitcoin maximalist in 2014, by Vitalik and others. After people kept asking me about it, I decided to use it as a geuzen-name: "a pejorative term used with pride by the people called that way." https:// en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geuzen#Or igin_of_the_name …

To be clear, I don't think that Bitcoin will ever be the sole cryptocurrency in the world, but rather that it will continue to dominate in market cap and serve as the basis for the internet of money. #schellingpoint #networkeffects #modularscaling #leanblockchain #immutability

Now that BTC is credibly going after smart contracts, high speed transactions, better privacy, and is winning hard-fork wars and institutional custody solutions - it's becoming safer to self-identify as a #BitcoinMaximalist . I am one, too! https:// twitter.com/Joi/status/931 008477249536001 …

It wasn't all that hard to get consensus to do a safe blocksize increase via segwit among the competent side of the 2X debate. That's because the real disagreement is about centralization. For instance, whether a tiny group meeting in a NY hotel should control Bitcoin's future.

With Core-vs-2X, the story isn't two differing opinions on the right way to scale Bitcoin; the real story is one side trying to build a decentralized currency, and another side w/ various motivations to make Bitcoin more centralized (who happened to have some incompetent devs).

Within the competent side of Bitcoin, there's actually a lot of disagreement; I personally think much of the long-term direction and focus of Bitcoin Core is misguided. But those disagreements are minor compared to how batshit crazy the 2X/BCH/Craig Wright side is.
